abstract: The bank regulator said it expected Chinese banks to extend loans totaling about $1.1 trillion this year, a decline of nearly 22 percent from 2009.
snippet: The bank regulator said it expected Chinese banks to extend loans totaling about $1.1 trillion this year, a decline of nearly 22 percent from 2009.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Chinese authorities signaled Wednesday that bank lending would slow significantly this year, the latest in a series of moves intended to forestall inflation and stave off bubbles in the stock and property markets.

headline.main: China to Slow Lending to Fight Inflation
headline.print_headline: China to Slow Lending to Fight Inflation

abstract: Chinese state-owned metals trader Sinosteel plans to file for an initial public offering of Chinese A-shares before March and get all required approvals by June, Sinosteel president Huang Tianwen was quoted as saying on Thursday.
snippet: Chinese state-owned metals trader Sinosteel plans to file for an initial public offering of Chinese A-shares before March and get all required approvals by June, Sinosteel president Huang Tianwen was quoted as saying on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Sinosteel, the Chinese state-owned metals trader, plans to file for an initial public offering of Chinese A-shares before March and get the required approvals by June, Huang Tianwen, the president of Sinosteel, was quoted as saying on Thursday, Reuters reported.

headline.main: Sinosteel Said to Seek I.P.O. Approval by June

abstract: China punished some banks, including Bank of China, for lending too much, after a surge in new loans this year increased inflationary pressures, sources said on Wednesday citing central bank figures.
snippet: China punished some banks, including Bank of China, for lending too much, after a surge in new loans this year increased inflationary pressures, sources said on Wednesday citing central bank figures.
lead_paragraph: China punished some banks, including Bank of China, for lending too much, after a surge in new loans this year increased inflationary pressures, sources said on Wednesday citing central bank figures, Reuters reported.

headline.main: China Said to Punish Banks for Overlending

abstract: Motorola unveiled an applications store in China for its phones that run Google’s Android software. The moves position the company to support Android even if Google leaves that country.
snippet: Motorola unveiled an applications store in China for its phones that run Google’s Android software. The moves position the company to support Android even if Google leaves that country.
lead_paragraph: If Google follows through on its threat to leave China, Motorola is ready to adapt.

headline.main: Google or Not, Motorola Pushes Forward on Android in China
